results.title: Young Voices of Mirboo North
results.creator_credit: David Withers, Csilla Csongvay and ACMI
results.brief_description: Do you want to know what this generation really thinks? Hear from the youth of Mirboo North, as they discuss matters of importance such as their future hopes, the threat of climate change and what they would miss most about living in their town.

results.title: Little journey
results.creator_credit: Keith Nguyen, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Keith remembers little of his early years - separated from his parents and living with his grandparents. His father had been sent to a Re-education Camp and his mother had moved away. On his father’s release from the Camp the family was reunited and several years later they escaped from the hardships of Vietnam to seek a better life in Australia.

results.title: Living in Locky: The Youth Perspective
results.creator_credit: David Withers, Astrid Scott and ACMI
results.brief_description: 17 year old Locky local, Emma McInnes interviews a cross section of young people to find out what life in a rural town is really like. What is there to do? What the future holds and the all important question, are there many lookers in Locky?

results.title: Jamieson Primary School
results.creator_credit: David Withers, Jessica Scott and ACMI
results.brief_description: The town of Jamieson, in north-eastern Victoria, is fiercely proud and protective of its historical primary school. With a school population hanging on for dear life, they understand only too well how much a primary school is the beating heart of a small community. It is also a place where life-long friendships are forged, and the school community (past and present) come together here to reflect on the ties that bind them to Jamieson. Principal Genevieve Bolwell also discusses the exciting school programs, which will take the next generation into the future.

results.title: The Lorne Theatre
results.creator_credit: Kim Montgomery, Jason White, Astrid Scott and ACMI
results.brief_description: Established over 90 years ago, the Lorne Theatre came about when a travelling picture show man ran out of funds and some local business men purchased his equipment and started running movies in the local hall. It then moved to its present site in 1937, where for such a small permanent population, the theatre has not changed much in all those years. Tony Hill, Manager of the Lorne Theatre, talks about the difficulties in offering a diverse range of cinema in the climate of DVDs and downloadable movies, and operating in a town prone to blackouts. He is proud the theatre is attended by a local group of cinephiles who sit in the same seat every session, and thinks himself very lucky to have his job.

results.title: DAK: David Alexander Kopelman
results.creator_credit: Roberto Salvatore, David Withers and ACMI
results.brief_description: yDAK doesn’t consider himself an artist, he just “dabbles and makes stuff”. Despite this his scrap-metal sculptures and decorative gates can be found throughout the neighbourhoods, businesses and galleries of the Bass Coast in south-eastern Victoria. Cape Woolamai’s very own mo-hawked road warrior has a plasma cutter and he’s not afraid to use it!

results.title: Time to fly
results.creator_credit: Belle Willox, Liam O'Bree and ACMI
results.brief_description: Belle Willox joined the WAAAFs because she always wanted to be a flyer like Amy Johnson. She joined when she was 18 and, though she never got to pilot a plane herself, there were certainly many ups and downs during her time in the war.

results.title: An Interview with Brigadier John P.A. Deighton
results.brief_description: John Deighton admits that at 18, everyone believes that they are bulletproof but the adventure of war stops when people start dying. He believes that the instant replay effect and the televisation of the Vietnam War was a factor in its unpopularity. He remembers the poor treatment Vietnam vets received on their return and how unfair it was as they were just doing their job.

results.title: Loch Ladies
results.creator_credit: Roberto Salvatore, Csilla Csongvay and ACMI
results.brief_description: This film showcases the many women who drive business in the small Loch Village. The four women featured are representative of the many others who are involved in running businesses in the main street of Loch. These women are smart, funny, hard working and driven individuals who have turned their passion into profit.

results.title: Community banking Bass Coast
results.creator_credit: Roberto Salvatore, David Withers and ACMI
results.brief_description: Early in 2001, the banks pulled out of the small coastal town of San Remo in south eastern Victoria, leaving the community with a challenge. Rather than sit on his hands and accept the inevitable consequences of downsizing, a local hardware store owner, Terry Ashenden, pulled together a committee of residents and business owners to overcome the problem.
